articles.content:
‚ÄòThe Testament of Ann Lee‚Äô Showcases the Minimalist Ingenuity of Shaker Furniture
Recreating the industrious world of the Shakers wasn‚Äôt just movie magic‚Äîit required conservators, curators and artisans
A place for everything and everything in its place. Actress Amanda Seyfried invokes the adage rhythmically as the titular character in director Mona Fastvold‚Äôs The Testament of Ann Lee, a movie musical that follows the beginnings of the Shakers, a Protestant sect of Christianity that became known as much for their ecstatic movements as their commitment to self-sufficiency. This phrase, often associated with the Shakers, has come to mean more than just a devotion to tidiness.
The film portrays Ann Lee, the 18th-century matriarchal founding figure of the sect, as she leads her followers from England to the United States in pursuit of religious freedom. She is guided not only by divine vision but toward a tangible destination: a stretch of untamed land outside Albany, New York, ringed by towering trees. There, Shaker beliefs will give rise to an austere, utilitarian material culture‚Äîwooden furniture and tools with clarity of form that come to define an iconic American design language.
But the Shakers themselves have nearly vanished. By the mid-19th century, about 4,000 to 5,000 practicing Shakers lived in 19 major villages across the U.S. Today, partly because of their strict adherence to celibacy, only three Shakers remain in the country, residents of Sabbathday Lake in Maine. Yet their objects endure. Their dovetail joints and ladder-back chairs continue to circulate in museums, homes and now cinemas. The Testament of Ann Lee traces how Shaker values were embedded in their labor and materials, and shows how that knowledge has been preserved for more than 150 years.
Quick fact: Amanda Seyfried as Ann Lee
Seyfried has received acclaim for her portrayal of the Shaker founder, which earned her a Golden Globe nomination.
Translating the Shakers‚Äô material world to the screen required a design approach grounded not in style but in study. Sam Bader, the film‚Äôs production designer, began by immersing himself in the visual record of the period‚Äîwoodcuts, lithographs, watercolors and drawings. ‚ÄúI was understanding the spatial and functional logic of each space,‚Äù he explains, ‚Äúfrom the laundry rooms to the kitchens to the workshops to the basket weaving.‚Äù Rather than recreating iconic objects, Bader focused on restoring the rationale that governed how objects, bodies and spaces related to one another. Everything needed a reason to be where it was.
That logic shapes the film‚Äôs visual progression. The Testament of Ann Lee does not open in the spare, rectilinear Shaker villages that now dot the East Coast. Instead, it begins in Manchester, England, ‚Äúchaotic and cluttered and nonrectilinear,‚Äù as Bader describes it. Interiors are dense with ornament, saturated in color and filled with repurposed objects.
Only gradually does the film arrive at the furniture forms most closely associated with the Shakers. The ladder-back chair, the clean geometry of wooden joinery and even the careful construction of Ann Lee‚Äôs casket appear later. This delayed reveal underscores the film‚Äôs central commitment: Shaker craft is presented not as an aesthetic choice but as the consequence of labor and necessity. ‚ÄúIt was about understanding what life would have been like for the early Shakers,‚Äù Bader says, ‚Äúas they were turning untilled forest land into a settlement.‚Äù As trees are felled, textiles woven and herbs gathered, form emerged from the beliefs that united the Shakers in these American settlements.
That authenticity depends on acts of preservation that long predate the film. Bader consulted a rare farming and housing survey at the New York Public Library‚Äîa mid-20th-century document meticulously recording joints, fastenings and construction techniques. He revisited Ken Burns‚Äô 1984 documentary, The Shakers: Hands to Work, Hearts to God, and consulted with the Shaker Museum in Chatham, New York, and Hancock Shaker Village in Pittsfield, Massachusetts. These archives‚Äîobjects, images, texts and oral histories‚Äîform the substrate from which the film‚Äôs images are built.
Objects like wooden tools and furniture can‚Äôt be fully understood through drawings alone. Their weight, texture, wear and construction are essential details for a film intent on portraying Shaker history. But keeping these pieces alive is no easy task. Paige Schmidt, wooden objects conservator at the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, describes historical objects as ‚Äúprimary records‚Äù‚Äîfirsthand documents of how people made and used things. Her department cares for collections spanning pre-Colonial Indigenous sites to 20th-century architectural landmarks, but the principle remains the same: Intervention must be minimal. ‚ÄúAs soon as I intervene with an object, I am potentially altering that record,‚Äù she says.
When Schmidt‚Äôs team receives a wooden artifact, they assess its structural stability, noting where the object has weathered, decayed or shown marks of use. They then conduct extensive documentation (photographic, UV, infrared and even X-ray) before any treatment begins. Larger interventions require collaboration with curators to clarify what the object will teach future audiences.
For utilitarian objects especially, preservation sometimes means accepting that function can no longer be restored. Schmidt mentions woven seats‚Äîa technique often employed by the Shakers when creating furniture. She notes, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a very good chance that those seats could not be sat in today without breaking,‚Äù but through careful filling in of breaks and losses to the weaving, a faithful representation of the object can remain as an educational tool.
Even when an object is carefully conserved, it still needs interpretation. Emily Orr, associate curator and acting head of product design and decorative arts at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum, points to the collection‚Äôs Shaker No. 7 rocking chair as an object full of knowledge.
The wood itself offers a wealth of information. ‚ÄúWe have our chair cataloged as being cherry or maple,‚Äù Orr says. ‚ÄúOne of the interesting things about the Shakers is that they not only had to learn joinery techniques but also learn about woods: What was locally available? How do you fell them? What could it be used for? Maple was often used in chair making‚Äîit was sturdy‚Äîso you see it composing pegs, slats, the posts of the chair.‚Äù
The forms that the materials take reveal what processes the Shakers had mastered. ‚ÄúThe really striking thing about the rocking chair is the bent slats on the bottom that allow the chair to rock,‚Äù Orr says. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs an educational opportunity to talk about steam bending. How do you make a flat, sturdy piece of wood turn into a rounded frame?‚Äù
The wood grain on the chair is very visible, Orr notes, because the Shakers avoided veneers, ornamental carvings and superfluous decoration. She emphasizes that the chair, unlike other 19th-century furniture, has no marquetry or painted surfaces or enamel. It‚Äôs ‚Äúnot hiding anything,‚Äù she says, adding that its beauty comes from its simplicity and symmetry.
Originally fitted with a rush seat, the chair would have been lightweight and portable. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs because the Shakers moved their furniture around,‚Äù Orr explains. ‚ÄúThis chair could have inhabited any number of spaces‚Äîmaybe a retiring room or a bedroom or even a more communal public space like a meeting room or a dining room.‚Äù She adds, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs made of natural, warm materials. It‚Äôs very much of the earth, anti-industrial. It‚Äôs a welcoming chair.‚Äù In the museum‚Äôs collection, the object itself acts as a keeper of history, revealing in its corners and curves both the quotidian life of the Shakers and their larger cultural values.
For The Testament of Ann Lee, preservation extended beyond objects to embodied knowledge. Timber-frame joinery specialist and conservator Michael Burrey, an instructor at the North Bennet Street School, was enlisted to recreate Shaker hand processes on camera. Bader says he‚Äôs one of the few people ‚Äúwalking around with all of the arcane knowledge of how this stuff was done.‚Äù
Burrey appears in the film, performing the labor that underpinned early Shaker communities. ‚ÄúThe first thing we did was at Eastfield Village in New York State,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúWe were out in the woods in costume, using an ax to fell a tree‚Äîenacting the start of these communities that Ann Lee began.‚Äù
The work unfolded chronologically. ‚ÄúThe next day we were at Hancock Shaker Village, hewing out a log,‚Äù Burrey says. ‚ÄúTaking axes and broad axes, scribing lines, following those lines to create four surfaces for a square timber.‚Äù
Later, inside the workshops, the tasks became smaller and more precise. ‚ÄúWe were shaving trunnels‚Äîtree nails or pegs‚Äîon a shaving horse with a knife.‚Äù They were also glazing windows, planing boards and drilling holes for pegs, all with tools powered by hand.For Burrey, the significance lies not only in techniques but in the cognitive processes they reflect. He encourages looking closely at how the frame of the Shakers‚Äô round barn is put together in the film. It had to be planned and executed without modern machinery, relying instead on hand tools and human-powered mechanisms to assemble and raise massive timber frames. ‚ÄúThink about all the knowledge that has to go into that,‚Äù Burrey says, ‚Äúwithout modern cranes or computers.‚Äù
That way of thinking shapes every loom, ax and tool that populates The Testament of Ann Lee. As Bader notes, ‚ÄúAnything you saw being made or created or spun wanted to have some kind of narrative payoff.‚Äù Watching trees being felled, land being tilled, textiles being woven, and food being prepared grounds the film‚Äôs spiritual story in physical survival.
Despite their disappearing communities, Shakers‚Äô craft persists‚Äîthrough conservators who protect objects as records, curators who teach us how to study, artisans who embody knowledge and films, like The Testament of Ann Lee, that reanimate belief through labor. And through careful preservation and re-creation, everything is still, remarkably, in its place.

articles.content:
Archaeologists Say They‚Äôve Finally Found a Long-Lost Basilica That Matches the Description the Architect Wrote 2,000 Years Ago
The structure is the first known evidence of a building attributed to Vitruvius, the author of an architectural treatise that influenced thinkers like Leonardo da Vinci
Archaeologists have unearthed the stone remains of a 2,000-year-old basilica designed by Vitruvius, a Roman architect and engineer.
Located in the Italian city of Fano, the basilica is the first physical evidence of a building attributed to the architect. Vitruvius is known as the author of De Architectura, an influential ten-book treatise from the first century B.C.E.‚Äîand the only surviving architectural text from classical antiquity.
Historians matched the layout of the basilica in Fano to descriptions of a building by Vitruvius in the fifth book of De Architectura. For centuries, archaeologists have searched for the structure, which, as Vitruvius wrote, was ‚Äúcarried into execution in the Julian colony of Fano.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt is a sensational finding ... something that our grandchildren will be talking about,‚Äù Alessandro Giuli, Italy‚Äôs culture minister, said at a news conference on January 19, as Reuters‚Äô Alvise Armellini reports.
The rectangular structure was built with ten columns on its longer sides and four columns on each of its shorter sides. The columns were about five feet in diameter, and they once stood nearly 50 feet tall.
Archaeologists were thrilled when Vitruvius‚Äô millennia-old designs, which detailed pilasters and corner supports, matched the newly discovered structure. Officials are confident that the basilica is indeed the work of Vitruvius, whose ideas on proportionality inspired Leonardo da Vinci‚Äôs Vitruvian Man.
Quick fact: What is Vitruvian Man?
- Around 1490, Leonardo da Vinci made this drawing, which examines the proportions of the human body.
- The artwork was based on ideas by Vitruvius, who did not include illustrations alongside his text.
‚ÄúWe have [an] absolute match,‚Äù Andrea Pessina, the regional archaeological superintendent, told reporters, per Reuters. ‚ÄúThere are few certainties in archaeology ‚Ä¶ but we were impressed by the precision.‚Äù
The ancient basilica was built at Fanum Fortunae, a settlement on the Adriatic Sea named after a local temple to the Roman goddess of fortune. But the historic city, which came to be named Fano, has been no stranger to misfortune. Multiple destructive events over hundreds of years‚Äîincluding the Napoleonic Wars of the 1800s and attacks during World War II‚Äîhave contributed to the loss of Roman-era buildings.
The first signs of the discovery emerged in 2022, when excavations at the nearby Via Vitruvio revealed walls and pavement made of marble, ‚Äú[suggesting] the presence of a high-status structure in the vicinity,‚Äù Artnet‚Äôs Min Chen writes.
Italian officials are already pushing for UNESCO to give the basilica protected status, and additional excavations will determine the extent of the surviving structure. Meanwhile, experts are still determining whether the site can be made accessible to the public.
‚ÄúThis remarkable discovery truly represents something exceptional in the history of archaeology, architecture and the morphology of the city of Fano, whose enormous importance we had already recognized,‚Äù Giuli said at the news conference, per ANSA.

articles.content:
This Detachable Robotic Hand Can Scurry Around and Grasp Objects Just Like Thing From the Addams Family
With up to six fingers that can bend in multiple directions, the innovative tool could one day be used to carry out tasks in tight spaces
A new robotic hand resembles a beloved character from the Addams Family franchise. Like the sentient human hand called Thing, the mechanical limb can scurry around and operate on its own‚Äîin ways a person‚Äôs hand never could.
The device can detach from a magnetic arm, crawl, grasp and carry multiple objects, and its fingers even bend backward. The creation, described in a study published January 20 in the journal Nature Communications, could one day serve as a prosthetic or perform tasks in tight spaces.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a dream of mine for many, many years to design a new hand which departs from anthropomorphic hands,‚Äù says study co-author Aude Billard, a roboticist at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne, to Skyler Ware at Science News. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs allowing people to think out of the box, to rethink what it is to have a hand or finger.‚Äù
Fun fact: The Addams family‚Äôs origins
Members of the Addams family made their debut as cartoon characters in The New Yorker in 1938, although they didn‚Äôt receive names until their TV show aired in 1964.
Engineers have long been inspired by the human hand, which is often considered the ‚Äúultimate embodiment of dexterity,‚Äù the researchers write in the paper. But it still has limitations‚Äînamely, that pesky arm that keeps it bound, and fingers and a palm that grasp only on one side.
To build a more agile robotic version, Billard and her colleagues first used a machine learning algorithm to determine the optimal design of the hand. Once they had several blueprints, they built the robot‚Äîwhich can accommodate up to six fingers‚Äîusing silicone, electric motors and 3D-printed structures.
The scientists then conducted a series of tests of the robot‚Äôs dexterity and mobility. In one, the robot held a mustard bottle on one side of the hand while bending its remaining fingers backward to pick up a can of chips on the other side. The team also tested the hand‚Äôs ability to use its fingers as legs to shuffle across surfaces.
Ultimately, four or five fingers yielded the best balance, and the five-fingered version could stably hold objects weighing up to about 4.5 pounds, the researchers found.
Study co-author Xiao Gao, a roboticist now at Wuhan University in China, tells Ari Daniel at the New York Times that the robot could have practical applications in the future. For instance, it could crawl into a water pipe or a submarine‚Äôs engine room and remove dropped objects, he says. And Billard tells the outlet that with more research, the robotic hand might even function as a prosthetic.
The study ‚Äúis a beautiful example of what you can achieve if you approach robotic design without being weighed down by all the constraints of the human factor,‚Äù says Matei Ciocarlie, a mechanical engineer at Columbia University who wasn‚Äôt involved in the work, to Science News.
But it does have limitations, according to Nancy Pollard, a roboticist at Carnegie Mellon University who also wasn‚Äôt involved in the study. A digit that can flex in different directions may not be able to apply the same amount of pressure to an object as a human finger, she says to the Times. She also noted little evidence of the fingers manipulating held objects.
Still, Billard hopes the new robot will spark innovation. ‚ÄúI believe this is what science is about,‚Äù she tells the Times.
